Reviews.Title: The most SHOCKINGLY Brilliant TV ever for this price!!!
Reviews.Author: Craigy77
Reviews.Content: The most shockingly brilliant TV ever!!!!I must say that I took a very long time researching a 3D TV that had what I was looking for.  I read all the reviews of everyone on all review sites including Amazon.  After looking at TV's in different stores and online it came down to features and not really the price.  I would have spent $5 to 6K for a 3D TV including the 4K that could deliver what this one at $2100.00 has literally BLOWN away.  I received this Sony 70 this morning in great anticipation and I must tell you that It was a thrill to fire this thing up and get my settings to what I like.  A great start for anyone that doesn't have the Spears and Munsil HD calibration disc is to read EDWARD from (NC) review on June 30th 2013.  His settings will get you a great start then you can tweak the fine details.  I like a little more color so I boosted mine to 62 instead of the 48 that Spears & Musil suggest.  But everything else that Edward says you really need to take to heart because you will have great frustration if you don't.  That is what is so awesome about this 3D TV is the level of settings that you can tweak.  I have watched 3 3D Movies already and it literally Blew me away.  If yoy need more glasses Stay with the glasses that comes with your purchase, the Sony TDG-500P passive glasses are fantastic because they are so light and the design is flawless.  Other 3D glasses like what you get at the theater will work fine but the comfort of these is unmatchable.  Finally a shout out to those few who threw out negative reviews, I believe that some of you literally may have caught a once in a million lemon but other who throw out technical garbe like ghosting, flashlighting, clouding and not to buy an edge lit TV.  I feel very sorry for those of you who do not take the time to calibrate this BEAST of a TV that once you calibrate it probably there is none of the effects that these reviewers are throwing at you.  I am a CEO in the real world and I must pay attention to a lot of details in business.  This TV has all the details and more but you must know how to use it or you will overlook the buy of the Century.  Always buy the 5 year extended warranty the price is shockingly low for no worries for 5 years even though Sony is a great brand in reliability as a CEO I always recommend a warranty.  Thank you Amazon for the great service, the PILOT delivery agent was outstanding and performed his job with great customer service.  I recommend this 3D TV without any reservations.  Everyone have a happy and safe Holiday season.

Reviews.Title: Excellent TV
Reviews.Author: Jack "Tech dummie"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this TV as a replacement for the 70 inch Vizio that turned out to be defective.  It is mounted on the wall so I can't comment on the stand.  I figure that most people buying a tv this large probably will wall mount it.  The picture out of the box needed some adjustments.  I read other reviews by buyers that had a passion for fine tuning their TV's and just followed their suggestions.  Picture is excellent.  We don't use the 3D.  I could care less about it and there don't seem to be many channels that broadcast it.  We have the set as part of a surround sound system so we don't use the tv speakers. We also use our DVD player for streaming Netflix and Hulu since the sound goes thru the receiver.  We will probably eventually buy a Roku and plug it into the surround receiver.  I think that it looks great on the wall and everyone that sees it comments on the excellent picture.  We sit directly in front of the TV and there is no issue with the picture being viewed from a side angle.  We can see it from the nearby kitchen area that is part of our family room.  This is off-center and the picture is still excellent.  This TV was more expensive than the Sharp and Vizio but I have much more confidence in the Sony.  So far, it has been excellent in all respects..  I did see the new Sony 4k which was much more expensive but smaller.  That TV had a weird configuration with speakers built-in.  This took up a lot of space and added significantly to the dimensions of the TV.  I didn't need any tv speakers since we have a pretty sophisticated surround system.  The 4k picture is better because of the resolution but I am quite happy with the 1080 resolution.  Anyway,  I am very pleased with this set.  I also bought the 40 inch Sony for my wine/bar, which is typical Sony--excellent.  Buy it and enjoy it.

Reviews.Title: Another Sony
Reviews.Author: arthurbtx "art"
Reviews.Content: I have purchased Sony TV's for 50 years, i have yet to be disappointed with a Sony TV.  I could have purchased a 55 inch Samsung for the same price, but I was compelled to go with Sony. However I can'' seem to hook up my external powered speakers.The set was delivered , uncrated, and set up and checked out by the delivery crew. Good Service!

Reviews.Title: Almost perfect
Reviews.Author: J. Digeorgio
Reviews.Content: I had looked for a new TV for over a year and finally bought the 50 inch version of this Sony.  I didn't buy it from Amazon - I bought it at a local brick and mortar when it went on sale. I read reviews here about backlight bleeding and clouding - and thankfully, I don't seem to have any of that.  The picture quality is fantastic in my opinion.  I will be up front and say that I came from a 36" Sony Wega tube Style TV from the early 2000's. It was a 4:3 unit of course and it was not HD.  But it still had a very good picture for the time.  What finally pushed me to move to the flat panels was that I hate that much of the picture was cutoff on many programs due to the 4:3 aspect ratio.Compared to the Wega, this TV's picture quality in HD is so much better!  In fact, I looked at many TVs including plasmas - and while I like the plasmas for the black levels and refresh rates, I have a bright room and plasmas just aren't bright enough in bright areas (my opinion) - and I also found that dark scenes are very muddy with a plasma.  I did evaluations in the store comparing dark scenes - and with the plasma I could not make out what was in the scene when it was a really dark scene.In all, I thought the picture on this Sony was better or at least equal to anything I looked at - including Samsung, LG and Panasonic models.  I had looked at some Vizio models which I know many people love, but I didn't see anything that stood out in particular. I had looked at last years Sony models (EX and some HX models) and I thought this years models were better - at least in the lower price ranges.I think the viewing angle on this model is also quite good - better than many LCDs and better than some of last year Sony models.  Not as good as a plasma though.  I really don't have a problem with it however.  The sound is almost as good as my old Wega and that's saying a lot!As for cons - I don't like that it doesn't always connect to wireless quickly.  Sometimes it takes a few minutes or you have to go into the menu and refresh.  Seems like it can't resolve the DNS automatically at times.The screen is somewhat reflective - and that can be a hassle in the afternoons at times.  I usually close the blinds to reduce the glare.Lastly - I like the remote, but I wish it had a qwerty keyboard on the back like some of the Vizio models.  That would really help with searches.I like the free year of HuluPlus and Netflix - that's about $200 in savings right there.Overall - I am very happy with this unit and I have no regrets.  I hope it holds up as well as my old Sony Wega which is actually still working fine after 12 years.

Reviews.Title: Really awesome picture.
Reviews.Author: Computer Hardware Services
Reviews.Content: Well I am already a Sony fan and this is another one that hit the nail on the head for what I can afford. I am one of those that never buy a new car, find open box items that are like new and this one is another. The only drawback if there is one, it came without a remote. Not good the day I get it and a little on edge but after a phone call to Sony, a new one in 10 days. Other than that, so far so awesome. Fantastic for the price!

Reviews.Title: Very good
Reviews.Author: Abu Yusuf
Reviews.Content: I bought Sony  TV about 3 weeks ago, so far no issue. Only thing I noticed that TV takes about 10 seconds to turn on.

Reviews.Title: Great picture, easy setup
Reviews.Author: Mark Barker
Reviews.Content: I wall mounted this and purchased a Sony Blu-Ray and sound bar to go with it.  Picture is great.  It was a breeze to set up and connect to my house WiFi.  I have not done a firmware update to say how easy it is.  After limited TV viewing and < 10 movies I am completely satisfield.  I can't wait to try the 3D.

Reviews.Title: Great picture quality, all the other add-ons are badly designed.
Reviews.Author: A. Damle
Reviews.Content: This is a great TV if you are not concerned about Wi-FI and related applications. I was unable to see Netflix or HighDef YouTube movies using the wireless connection. However, I had connected Apple TV box to the TV and had no issues watching the same videos.Finally I bought the Netgear power line adaptor. It uses your home electrical circuit to communicate with the network and that resolved the speed  issue. I don't know why SONY hasn't worked on these issues.Tech support is in Philippines and they are helpful. I had to spend more than 3-4 hours to troubleshoot various issues.I have a Western digital cloud hard disk and when I try to see the MP4 format movies, it hangs. I have to disconnect the TV and reconnect it. The same MP4 movie works fine if it is copied on the Pen drive and watched using the USB port on the TV. I still don't know how to fix that issue. The internet browser is also nearly useless.

Reviews.Title: I love it!
Reviews.Author: Jane
Reviews.Content: My expensive Samsung 48 inch flat screen LCD TV died after only 4 years.  According to the TV repairman it was not even worth fixing.  After reading the reviews of every tv out there, I decided on the Sony and I am not sorry!  The difference in the picture amazed me.  Now let's hope it lives a long and healthy life!!

Reviews.Title: All in One TV
Reviews.Author: Frank Anderson
Reviews.Content: OMG! I have had this TV for about couple of months now and its one of the best purchase I have made.  Love the internet connectivity and i watch YouTube more than cable, i think its time to cut the cord.Now the 3D is okay nothing to be amazed but good thing to show off to friends.

Reviews.Title: Amazing TV!
Reviews.Author: Timothy
Reviews.Content: This TV is amazing!  It is smart so it knows when we are using our stereo or when the stereo is turned off it plays sound through the TV speakers.  It also has apps built in like amazon instant video, hulu, and netflix among others.  Very easy to use, intuitive and smart.  The picture is great also!  For the price there is no better 70" tv on the market!

Reviews.Title: you get what you pay for
Reviews.Author: keeping it real for everyone
Reviews.Content: Screen has clouding on completely black screens and dark screens in movies and shows. The clouding is less noticeable in movies and shows. Picture is good and smart functions work not the fastest but are ok. For half the price of a 75 samsung it is a good buy but is just not as good

Reviews.Title: Big, affordable TV
Reviews.Author: Kenneth Rinehart
Reviews.Content: I bought this TV (60 inch model) to replace a 55" Panasonic GT30. I liked the plasma a lot, but the room the TV is in presented light and reflection issues and I wanted something a little bigger. Here are the main points.Pros:* The picture is great after some tweaking. Dark blacks, colors pop.*3D is much better than the panasonic plasma I am coming from. Brighter and more "pop" (Active glasses, 2011)I prefer the cheap, light, passive glasses myself and am glad for the change.(Let's not debate active vs passive here, this is my subjective opinion).*Netflix app is very similar if not identical to the PS3 app.*Not as much glare as some other TVs I have had.Cons:*Some panel inconsistencies that are noticable if the screen is completely black and you stare at it for a while.These are never noticable when I am watching TV/Bluray/Gaming or I would reflect it in the rating. This is a common thing with LCDs.*Confusing picture adjustment with "scenes" as well as the more detailed settings available in Home and Options.Took a while to get a grip on what did what, or find the game mode to reduce game lag.As long as nothing crops up within the next week or so I am content with the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Dead out of the Box!
Reviews.Author: Warren Eads III
Reviews.Content: So after "White Glove" delivery (that is supposed to consist of unpacking and hooking up to a power source and removal of the packing) that consisted of dude asking me where to put the box only, I open the box, attach a wall mount bracket and hang on the wall. Dead. No standby LED, no power LED, no nothing.The advertised delivery was not. The TV is dead, and now I have two options. Amazon return or Sony customer support.This TV was to be a replacement for a 2006 Bravia. Love that TV but lacking in features now. I have to decide to hang it back up in the interim or go without a TV for a while.I will keep you updated on what transpires.

Reviews.Title: Love this TV - Great Quality and Features!
Reviews.Author: HN89
Reviews.Content: Edit (after a couple weeks):I've done Xbox gaming, PS3 gaming, 3D (The Hobbit, Avatar, and others), Streaming (local network, Netflix), and have a PC hooked up to it. I love this TV! I couldn't be more happy with the quality.Day 2 Review:I may or may not end up coming back to update this but figured I would write my initial impressions.The picture quality is great. Watched Avatar 3D, played some Xbox 360, Netflix, and played around with settings quite a bit. The viewing angle is superior to my previous televisions. We had a sectional with a side that we had a hard time seeing our previous TV, I can barely see any distortion from extreme side angles now. The glare on the screen is minimal, with lights on in the room the picture is still very visible. I spent some time looking closely for dead pixels and couldn't find any. Also no sign of the white glow issue some reviews have mentioned.The apps are very responsive (relative to a Vizio TV I have). Setup Netflix, Amazon Prime, and HuluPlus. Also tried some of the other apps - an HD Scenes app, and a 3D demo app.We didn't have any trouble getting the 12 months of Netflix credited to our already existing account. That was one question I had about the 12 months free Netflix promotion - whether it could be applied to an existing account - it can! We also created a new HuluPlus account with the free 12 months.Mounted this on a B001LL5JDAVery nice mount! Anyways, we didn't mess with the stand that came with the TV so I can't comment too much on that. The front bottom of the TV is like chrome and reflective. I would have preferred this to not be like that, but I noticed while watching a movie that it wasn't distracting.I'm using the external audio, so I ran an optical audio cable from the TV to my sound receiver which worked fine.Overall very happy with the purchase and no regret at this point for making the decision to go with Sony (was also considering similarly priced Vizio).

Reviews.Title: Decent display, bad smart features
Reviews.Author: Evil Hubie
Reviews.Content: If you're planning to use this TV solely as an HD / 3D display, you'll be OK. Picture is fine, not without flaws. We've had an issue with flickering (poorly designed energy saver?), and the video occasionally stutters a bit (processor limitations with MotionFlow?), but it's passable for things like watching from the cable box.The smart features of the TV, however, are horrifically, facepalm-inducingly poor. The TV is very limited in what video and audio formats it can play. Browsing though the contents of DLNA servers takes literally minutes. Media listings don't include the name of the media-- you have to click on each file to see what it is. There's no way to fast forward quickly in a video (I think the fastest is 4x, and sometimes not at all for certain formats). The remote is a standard button-based remote, which makes browsing essentially a non-starter. And there isn't an immediately obvious YouTube app.If you like smart features, find a different TV.

Reviews.Title: No competition at this price level for what this TV offers (which is light blobs)
Reviews.Author: E. Harris
Reviews.Content: I had to change this rating to a 1 star due to some really bad flashlighting, light blobs, and uniformity issues.  Until I can get one that isn't glaringly noticeable, this will be a 1 star tv.  This TV gives you a 70" with amazing theater like passive 3D, with wow factor picture quality and impressive black levels for an LED, all at a reasonable price.  There is currently no other TV that can give you all that.Here's the skinny on this TV.  (reviewing 70")- amazing black levels (not mine, terrible light blobs and flashlighting ruin black levels)- impressive picture quality- great 3D quality, with almost no crosstalk- great for games with very little input lag- LED drawbacks like flashlighting and clouding only noticeable when actual content isn't playingHere's why I love this TV.  Passive 3D is amazing.  It is so natural feeling and no strain on your eyes because your glasses are not flickering like active 3D.  Simply one eye blocks out one image and the other blocks out the 2nd image.  And as long as you are sitting up straight, and not at an EXTREME angle, you will hardly ever notice any ghosting in 3D what-so-ever.  3D on this TV looks natural, has incredible depth, and looks so smooth because of the lack of crosstalk.  If you are buying this TV for 3D, you need not be worried.The Black levels are also amazing.  I had to go back and change my review.  I initially called them very good.  I have yet to try a "black level demo" that has failed to impress me.  I'd now rate contrast ratio and black levels at 4.5/5 (whereas the panny flagship plasma's are 5/5).  It's damn good for an LED.As far as gaming I think the input lag is minimal.  I am no expert but one "test" I use for input lag is pinball games, because the lag between you hitting a button and the flipper going off is one of the easiest ways to tell how badly the screen is lagging.  And trust me, I have seen some bad lag in the past.  I played Pinball Arcade on the PS4 and the flipper response time seemed immediate.  So I was very happy.  Not to mention the fact that the picture quality of this TV combined with PS4's 1080p gaming is pretty beautiful to behold.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous Picture
Reviews.Author: amazonian
Reviews.Content: The colors are so vibrant compared to other TVs in this price range.  Also it doesn't look distorted or fade out if you are sitting off to the side a ways.  For the price it's great quality.

Reviews.Title: Best of the 70" TV's
Reviews.Author: J. Leafgreen "consumer friend"
Reviews.Content: I looked and looked for a quality TV in the 70" size. I was trying to replace an LG 55LH90, which I consider to be the best LED TV to date. I was not thrilled with the Vizio E or M series, especially the lack of controls actually on the counsel for the Vizio M. I am not a fan of active 3D either so Sharp was not a great option. In Sharp's case, the only comparable model (70LE857U) to this Sony is actually more expensive. I have had the Sony for 3 days now. While I did see the TV in a store before purchasing, I was not instantly impressed after taking it out of the box. However, after several tweaks to the settings, this is a fabulous TV. I also purchased a Sony 3D Blu-ray with it and the family watched Epic in 3D. The passive 3D on this set is better than the theater. In all, I consider this to be a high quality TV but still not what my LG is. If you have to have a 70" TV, then this is the one. If you simply need a large TV, then you have considerably more options in the 65" - 75" range and can likely find slightly better. Keep in mind that the 80" TVs are only beefed up versions of the 70" market. I had to have a 70" to fit perfectly in a space, thankfully I was able to keep my LG in another room.

Reviews.Title: This is the tv I really like.
Reviews.Author: Albert Chu
Reviews.Content: Everything in this tv is up to my expectation, especially the price, the picture quality, the ease of use, in short, this is the tv I heartily like.

Reviews.Title: Very good 70 inches tv
Reviews.Author: Cho Jang Woo "ninza"
Reviews.Content: sony 70r550a !!!Very good 70 inches tvPassive 3D way too easyscreen is brightpicture quality was awesome.

Reviews.Title: KDL-50R550A just an ok purchase
Reviews.Author: B. Ben "coffee guy"
Reviews.Content: I'm going to do my best to give a fair and accurate review of my BB purchased KDL-50R550A, purchased 11/2013, Serial Number beginning with 604.PROs-It's one of the few 50" panels on the market.  There appears to be one 50" model per manufacturer, and in Sony's line-up for 2013, this is about it.  I would have purchased the upgrade KDL-55W900A in a heartbeat if it came in a 50" package.-The picture is tack sharp and looks amazing with a high quality feed.-The ultra thin bezel is gorgeous, with screen filling the entire package.  I was able to move from an older Samsung LN46A650 and actually save an inch or two in the process!-The stand is PERFECT and it being parallel to the screen (instead of that awful round chrome one on Sony's other models) allows for precise placement of a necessary sound bar.  I use an older Sony CT-100 sound bar and it fits perfectly in front of the screen and does not intrude up into the screen so thank you Sony for making the television just high enough to clear most sound bars.-The screen is not that reflective.  Awesome upgrade over my old Samsung and I see much less room reflections during the daytime!-Sony's 120hz setting is MUCH smoother than Samsung's in my opinion without the weird stuttering when the camera pans on some broadcast shows.-Passive 3D is the only hope for 3D...great job Sony in moving the market in this direction.  Zero cross talk and amazing clarity.  Passive 3D glasses are cheap, light as a feather, and don't cause nearly as much headaches as Active 3D glasses.CONs-There is no color pop with this set.  Zero, zilch, nada.  If you want color pop, then be prepared for skin tones to suffer...I just can't find the right combinations to prevent everyone looking like they're sun baked.  There was a time when Sony skin tones were the standard for all other manufacturers.  That's not the case any longer.-Blacks are generally crushed but there is some shadow detail.-Video processing is sub par.  Lots and lots of grainy noise and I'm certain Sony says, 'Hey what did you expect for sub 1k pricing?'-Now the BIG complaint...concentrated brighter lighting in the bottom left hand corner of the screen!  Some call it flashlighting, which is exactly what it looks like.  Some reviewers on various websites state that their screens are brighter in all four corners, or in both bottom left and right hand corners but regardless, there are issues with flashlighting on these sets.  I have several weeks left before I have to decide whether to return the set to BB or not.  I was able to reduce the flashlight in the lower left hand corner by reducing the backlight setting to 2 sometimes 3, but that's a band aid solution.I'll be honest, it's a pain to return one of these large televisions only to think will the next one be worse so with flashlighting only on the lower left hand side, I'm inclined to learn to ignore it.  Sony, a little QC would go a long way to helping rebuild your storied name in consumer electronics.A couple of thoughts.  Google's informal corporate motto at one time was, 'Don't be evil.'  I don't know if Google holds true to that motto or not, but one thing is clear when reading Amazon's reviews, they take care of their customers without hassle.  In fact, look at Amazon's site as of the date of this review.  They stopped selling this model temporarily because they're concerned there are too many complaints on this television.Kudos to Amazon for using their tremendous influence to prevent hassle to their customers.My current settings:StandardBacklight 3 generally but 2 for some night viewingPicture MaxBrightness 50Color 54Hue 0Sharpness 13Color Temperature NeutralNoise Reduction LowMPEG Noise Reduction OffAdv. Contrast Enhancer MediumBlack Corrector OffGamma +1Clear White Low (This seems to help with the overly red skin tones)Live Color Low (The only way to get some color pop; hurts skin tones)LED Motion Mode Off

Reviews.Title: Great tv until we had issues
Reviews.Author: R. B. "R.B."
Reviews.Content: The picture quality was great, the best.  The passive 3D is fantastic.  The glasses are cheap and it really does work.  Watching movies in 3D are so amazing!  The problem is that we bought it on 26 Sept and now on 18 Dec, the picture quality is junk.  It looks like I am watching a cheap video on a slow computer...not smooth at all.  I reset it to factory settings and no good.By the way, I got the Disney WOW dvd and was not needed.  From the factory, the setting came out the same, so I figured resetting to the factory specs, all is good, not so.  I contacted Sony via chat and after an hour, I was left with...update firmware, done before I did the chate but tried again as told by the rep...no good.  I reset it to factory settings, done before I chatted...no good.  I unplugged it and waited 60 sec...no good.In the end, I was given a link so that I can fill out the information to get a repair cost! not good.  It's a brand new tv.  I should have gottne the extended warrenty for an additional $200.  In the end, it was a terrific tv before it broke.  Now it is just garbage.  I will not by any more Sony product.  It's too bad.

Reviews.Title: It's OK
Reviews.Author: Elisiano Petrini
Reviews.Content: The quality of the panel is not as good as in other models.All in all I'm pretty satisfied by the builtin media features of the TV (although fast forward over DLNA does not work for me) and by the size (it is pretty big).This is really a case of 'you get what you pay for' (but can't beat the price/size).

Reviews.Title: Wonderful TV with good image and sound
Reviews.Author: amywu
Reviews.Content: Very good image and sound. There is light leakage for black screen, which I don't care much but you might.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: Paul Corcoran
Reviews.Content: This tv is an excellent value. I have worked in the television production field for almost 30 years and I have to admit I was a little reluctant to purchase an LED tv. Most inexpensive LED sets I saw have problems handling fast motion and lack good black levels. This TV handles motion very well and has rich black levels. There are certainly some that are better than this one but they will cost a LOT more money. This tv also came with 6 months free Netflix and 1 year 0f HuluPlus ($140 value)

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: cables
Reviews.Content: Great TV, looks amazing and very easy to use. The built in Netflix and other Smart Apps add a ton of value.

Reviews.Title: Great TV with one major problem
Reviews.Author: Gabriela Drosu
Reviews.Content: Pros: fantastic image, great 3D or simulated 3D, easy to use menu.Cons: Whitish spots on the screen that kill the dark images. I tried to change the settings to no avail (reduce backlit, brightness, etc.). I really like the unit but it is hard to ignore the uneven screen illumination. Another problem is the useless web browser. It does not have Flash and it is quite difficult to type with the TV's remote.I am working with Sony's tech support to have this issue resolved, but most probably I will have to return it. Not sure if this is a common problem or I just ended up with a defective unit.

Reviews.Title: Great great
Reviews.Author: William LINDER
Reviews.Content: great great great tv worth every penny great color great picture and games look great while playing it by far one of the best tvs ive owned

Reviews.Title: Wonderful TV
Reviews.Author: CAT
Reviews.Content: I really like this Sony 50" TV. I feel the color and picture is outstanding, and seems to get better the longer I have it. I haven't tried the 3D yet so I can't comment on that, but I must say as others have mentioned, the sound could be better. The speakers on many of the new, thinner TV's are on the bottom, and so the sound is directed downward then out. To me, it's a bit distorting, and the voices sound muffled. In the beginning, I had to use headphones in order to make out many of the words, in movies especially.Yesterday, I went to our local Bose store, and bought their Solo TV Sound System. Got it for only $279.00 since it was an open box item... otherwise, I would have purchased it here on Amazon.com.(Bose%C2%AE Solo TV Sound SystemThis sound system has made ALL the difference in the world. I can now actually hear/understand every word that is spoken so it makes this TV all that much more enjoyable. This is a bedroom TV that is hung on the wall in a room that is about 16x15 so not so big that I should have trouble hearing. Anyway, I am very satisfied with my purchase now! Would highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Almost a 5 star, but...
Reviews.Author: R. Naylor "Gadget Geek"
Reviews.Content: Great price (although dropped $400 in two months from when I bought it) and great quality picture.  I bought two high end color tuning DVD's, but didn't really need them as they were adjusted perfectly out of the box.The reason for the 4 star is that every once in a while, the picture will black out with my HD Tivo and need to power the TV off and on again.  Also, it will go to green screens trying to get the HDMI signal in sync often.  Turning the TV on takes about 10 seconds  or longer for an image to appear (the logo comes on in about 4 seconds).  Once you turn it off, you can't turn it back on right away as you need to wait a few extra seconds for some reason.  Also, the power light is so tiny, it is hard to tell if it is on or off when there is no signal.  The Smart TV functionality is just ok, compared to my new Samsung 60".A great set, but a fair number of quirks.

Reviews.Title: Clouding issues, had to exchange TV
Reviews.Author: Botgirl
Reviews.Content: So, I bought this TV four days ago, and out of the box, the lower left-hand corner had very visible backlight bleeding. I called Sony, and was told to call back when I was in front of the television so they could fiddle with settings. I was clear with them that I already did that and it wasn't going to make a difference. I called back that night and described the issue (again), and was told they would send out a repairman and then someone would email me the days/times. The next day, I received a phone call from Sony asking me to email them photographs of the television rather than sending out a repair person.I was miffed, but I also realized that if I sent the photos, they might return the set and send me a new one because the lower left-hand corner clearly has an issue. This turned out to be exactly what they did. I emailed them the images and they wrote back within a few hours asking me to call them. I called them *again* and they said they would send out a new TV in the next 5-7 biz days. They took my credit card (and did a test charge against it, I see) and said that I would have to ship back (pre-paid by them) the old TV. I'm not sure how I'm supposed to disassemble this TV by myself and I'm really hoping the carrier will pick it up because it's not like I have a car or an easy way to transport 50 lb. objects. And I'm incredibly unhappy that I'm going to have to miss work for a TV delivery.But, I guess I'm pretty pleased with Sony's customer service so far. They're not at all fighting me on the issue. I'm just hoping the next set is in perfect condition.As for the set itself: even if this TV were perfect, if I had to do it all over again, I'm not sure I would. The screen is VERY glossy and reflects a ton of background lighting if you have other lights on in the room. The viewing angle is also pretty poor, although while in the store, it had the best viewing angle I could personally assess. It may just be that edge-lit LED LCD TVs (or all LCD TVs, for that matter) simply suck when it comes to viewing angle. The images on the screen itself look pretty good.I will give this TV set high marks for not having a terrible "Soap-opera effect" that seems to plague Samsung TVs in particular. Even with motion control on, the picture doesn't look too unrealistic when watching movies. I think I'm going to focus on that as my victory here because I cannot STAND the soap-opera effect.I think TV technology in genral is well behind the curve at this point. The quality just isn't there, and things like clouding and backlight bleeding shouldn't be acceptable. I'm glad that Sony seems to agree.I think I'll enjoy the TV for the most part when I finally get it in total working order, but I'm honestly not that jazzed by any TVs right now, and having it broken out of the box makes a large, expensive purchase demoralizing. Here's hoping OLEDs come down in price in the next 5 years and we can ditch this LED edge-lit crap.I'll post an update when I get the replacement.UPDATE:Nearly 10 days since my post. I've been calling Sony and getting stuck on hold for 20+ minutes at a time (3 times!) only to be pushed to other departments. I kept calling back, getting different answers. Finally, I was told that they can't give me a tracking number yet on my replacement TV because it takes 2 weeks to process. Um, that was new news after being told they should have a tracking number w/in 5 biz days.  I called AGAIN yesterday (8/24/13) and was told that their systems was down for maintenance and I should call back on Tuesday (!!) to find out if/what my tracking number is because they couldn't help me. How is their system down for maintenance for THREE DAYS? What? I'm getting annoyed, very annoyed.So, no replacement TV yet. This is pretty absurd.UPDATE: 9/5/2013I'm downgrading this review to a 2 star because I can't get adequately fast responses from Sony. I'm STILL waiting on a replacement. I've been posting to their Facebook page, and I'm getting near-immediate responses back saying, "We'll get back to you" and then they're not getting back to me. I got one yesterday saying they'd get back to me that afternoon--but no. At this point, I just want a refund. It's nearly a month since I bought this thing.UPDATE: 11/10/13I got the replacement TV sent to me by the end of September. I had the old TV shipped back to them. Sony paid for the shipping both ways. The new TV is better than the prior TV, but still has some clouding issues in the upper left-hand corner.The picture looks best with all motion control turned off--almost no "soap-opera" effect that way. I like the TV well enough, but I'm not blown away.BOTTOM LINE:If you have trouble with the TV, don't call Sony, just go to their Facebook page and post your complaint/concern there. You'll get the best response.I wouldn't purchase this TV again. Too much hassle for not enough TV. The viewing angle sucks, btw. I hope that TV technology improves in 5 years when I plan to replace it. Changing back to 3 star since this situation is now sorted.

Reviews.Title: Great TV and features
Reviews.Author: John A. Bradshaw
Reviews.Content: If you are wondering why I am stating that this is a great TV yet giving it one star, it is because of a few issues I have had.  I will upgrade/update my rating if they resolve the issue.I researched a lot of TV's to replace a smaller LCD as we moved into a new house and have a fireplace that has a pre-built mount for TVs.  The selection of TVs to choose from is pretty daunting however I chose this model due to its ratings, features and most of all the fact that it has a built-in DirectTV tuner (allowing me to have less electronics in the main living area).Upon receiving the new unit around 12/6/13, I had a buddy that professionally mounts and install TV's and theater systems, mount our unit.  He 'dialed it in' real quick.  I was highly impressed with the picture.  As always, I quickly turned off the Cinemotion and Motionflow features (I still cannot fathom for the life of me why this is a default feature...).  SIDE NOTE: Turning this feature off when renting Amazon Prime movies can be done by hitting the Settings button while in the Netflix app.  After several days I noticed thin faint black vertical lines running the entire height of the screen.  They were off center, one on the right and one on the left.  You could only see them when a brighter picture was displayed.  This happened on several my Blu-ray or my DirectTV box.  I replaced cables and tried several ports for each device but to no avail. I called Amazon and they were great (as always).  They said to call Sony first in this situation and to call them if Sony would not assist.Sony had me go through the usual task of changing settings to factory defaults, power reset and cable/port swaps.  Afterwards they referred me to the product replacement people.  They sent another TV which arrived around a week and half later (the carrier they used was horrible but that is another story).  I hung the new TV.  After several days, guess what...more faint black lines.  This time, three of them running vertically (looked more like 3 mini tornadoes).  Prior to this my wife thought I was nuts as she never noticed them.  Now, I am vindicated as she too sees them.  Again, it is only when a bright scene is on the screen.I go through the same process with Sony only this time they insist on sending me a "re-certified" unit as I already received a new replacement.  I made my case and demanded a new one.  After supplying a Amazon receipt, they agreed.  A new unit is en-route and my fingers are crossed.  I love this TV and its picture and features and truly hope the new unit resolves my issue although I must admit I am gun shy and fear the worst.  I will post back after the new unit is installed and tested.

Reviews.Title: You don't get what you paid for
Reviews.Author: Julia

Reviews.Title: Watching the Movies with My Dad
Reviews.Author: Stephanie Sane
Reviews.Content: For the longest time I had no TV. My twin Tiffany and I were raised all over the world by our old dad, a rock and roll roadie, songwriter, wine drinker and lover off all things wonderful. He gave us Paris, Hong Kong, Tokyo and Madrid, introduced us to Bob Dylan and Mick Jagger when we were only little girls. He was the best, he was the greatest and he loathed TV.He used to say there is no difference between watching the news, football, a sitcom or masterpiece theater -- you're sitting on your couch watching people in a box, who make a whole bleeping lot more money than you. Only he didn't say bleeping. That was his way of saying, go out and live your life, don't waste away your hours watching others.However, my old dad loved the movies. No matter where we were, come the weekend, he took us to whatever silver screen was closest. I can't tell you how many American movies I've seen dubbed into French and Spanish. My old dad loved a good movie.And so do I. All my life I've lived without a TV, until now. At Costco I saw this Sony Bravia 60 inch TV and I really, really wanted it. So now I have a TV. However, I don't have cable, don't have Dish Network, don't even have an antenna on my roof. No TV shows for me. Just movies. So Dad, if you're reading this from wherever you are, don't roll over in your grave, because when I turn out the lights at night and turn on this beautiful widescreen movie shower, it's you I'm sitting with.

Reviews.Title: Clouds & Flashlighting. An Edge-Lit Problem.
Reviews.Author: WARRZONE
Reviews.Content: First off, this TV is capable of producing great colors and 3D. All the functions work (although you do have to wait a few seconds after starting the TV to access SEN or Netflix). The 50" I received has horrible clouding and flashlighting on dark scenes and black bars when the room is dark. I called Sony, and they said this is perfectly normal for LED LCDs. If this is normal, I will not be buying anymore LED LCDs. I contacted the retailer about this problem and sent them a photo, and they said their floor model does not have this problem (I have a feeling their ambient lighting is too bright to see it though).All I've ever owned are LCDs (none edge-lit though), and they did not have this problem. I have a replacement set coming. If it has the same problems, I will be buying a plasma instead, since manufacturers for the most part are not making full array LED LCDs anymore. I suppose it's cheaper to replace the TVs of the people who complain rather than having a person to test them in the first place. Not many people bought the full array local dimming TVs because they were so expensive, so manufacturers gave up on them instead of further developing the technology to make it cheaper. The general public keeps buying edge-lit LCD TVs, so manufacturers have no reason to change.Bottom Line: Don't buy an edge-lit TV unless you can see and test the one you will be buying or unless you feel lucky. Edge-lit technology isn't up to par yet.Update: I received the replacement, and it is much better. There is no clouding, but there is still some flashlighting on three corners (and a tiny bit on the fourth). I will try it out for a week to see if I can live with it because I would much rather have an LCD with passive 3D than to have to baby a plasma.Update2: I decided to return it for a refund. Personally, I will never buy an edge-lit TV again unless I can see and test the exact TV I will be buying in the store with the lights off, which most stores won't do.

Reviews.Title: Unremarkable picture quality for the price and third-rate smart TV
Reviews.Author: E.S.
Reviews.Content: This TV appears to have it all for a reasonable price: 3D, smart TV with integrated wifi, and it's a Sony to boot!Sadly, despite the long feature list the set hardly lives up to the expectations due to some serious basic shortcomings.But first, the good:--The TV is thin and handsome and looks great in either a table or wall mount--Sound reproduction is better than the laptop-audio quality of other sets at this price point--4 HDMI inputs provide great connectivity--Color fidelity is passable once all the picture improvement gizmos intended to snazz up store displays are turned off.--3D is decent and the passive glasses are a pleasure to use--Matte panel handles room reflections graciously.And the bad:--Detailed calibration is unavailable. If you're interested in picture quality, look elsewhere. Skin tones give this set a hard time in particular.--Abysmal black levels. I don't have measurement equipment available, but it's evident at once that Sony didn't put their best foot forward here. See this set at your local store side-by-side with the modestly pricier Panasonic VIERA TC-P50ST60 50-Inch 3D Smart Plasma HDTV to experience the world of difference between the high-end of display technology and this rather ratty panel.--Smart TV features are bogged down in poor software design. Save yourself the trouble of trying to use the built-in Netflix, Amazon, and Hulu apps. The television can take several minutes to connect to your wifi network after turning it on. During this time all apps are unavailable. Once connected, expect frequent connection drops that require the TV to reboot and begin the whole process again. (FYI, I've tested the signal strength of the network near the TV and found it adequate. A couple of MacBooks, a Samsung Galaxy S3, an iPad and a Surface all manage to stream through hours of video without a hitch from the same location.) If you're really after online features in your TV, buy a cheaper TV with a similar-quality panel like the VIZIO E500i-A1 50-inch 1080P 120Hz LED Smart HDTV and pair it to an Apple TV. Keep the change and buy yourself a steak dinner.--The remote suffers two critical flaws: the "Home" button is right beneath the "Down" button, so you'll often hit "Home" when scrolling through the Netflix movie catalog. Good luck reloading the app without crashing or dropping the signal. Secondly, the remote isn't backlit. C'mon, Sony, it's 2013! Couldn't you at least use phosphorescent paint?All in all, this set is hardly a bargain when you consider that other companies make similar TVs for a couple of hundred dollars less or much refined models for an extra Benjamin.I regret letting myself be blinded by the Sony name and wish I'd gone with one of the other options I mentioned.

Reviews.Title: Good Picture, Poor Smart TV Functionality
Reviews.Author: DStellz
Reviews.Content: I decided to upgrade my 46" Samsung Smart LED TV, and this was reasonably priced and had the added benefit of 3D.Pros:The picture is great, and it's very easy to use. I like the fact the remote has a Netflix button, and there isn't a delay in the controls. The simulated 3D works surprisingly well, although I barely find myself using it truth-be-told. The glasses are comfortable and have not given me a headache.Cons:The "smart" features on this TV are horrible. The interface between Netflix and HuluPlus for this Sony TV is the worst I have seen. Using these apps on my other devices (PC/Xbox360/PS3/Samsung TV/Phone/Tablet) is far easier to use, and yields much better results.To give you an idea, the Netflix app fails to show me much more than my instant queue. I cannot flip through movies like I can on other devices. Instead, I have a huge grey screen, and when I scroll around it locks up and the yellow cursor doesn't line up with anything. Furthermore, it often fails to track my progress across whatever shows I am watching, and I frequently have to back out and go back into it for it to work. I never had this issue with Samsung.HuluPlus suffers from an awful interface, takes forever to find what I'm looking for, and lags like crazy. I've used it on PS3, and while still laggy (HuluPlus seems bad in general) it is nowhere near how bad it is as the Sony TV app.When the TV turns on, it takes a minute or two for it to connect to the internet and allow Netflix to open. Not a huge deal, but not common these days.I also didn't realize the extreme lack of 3D content out there. Barely any video games, channels, anything on Netflix, and I couldn't even find moderately decent 3D bluray movies in Walmart.It lacks HBOGo. This is simply unacceptable at this point. PS3 doesn't have this either, so I don't know what's going on with Sony.Final Impression:Keep an eye out for deals elsewhere. I've seen 60" Samsung LEDs go for significantly cheaper than this. My experience with their products has proved superior to my experience with Sony. For what this TV costs, it should yield more impressive functionality than what is offered. For a device to not run Netflix properly, especially one $1300+ is unheard of when you can now spend $35 for a Chromecast or $50 for an HD Roku.My advice is to scrap your dreams of having your own personal Sony 3D theater chock full of digital media to select without additional devices. You're better off saving yourself $300+ and getting another brand, lose the 3D (and smart functionality if you so wish) and pick yourself up a 60" Samsung/LG/Sharp.

Reviews.Title: HOPE THIS HELPS !!!
Reviews.Author: Janine
Reviews.Content: I will post this in different places I.e Samsung, Sony, and Vizio sections.OMG, choosing a car is much easier than a TV. As most people here, I have spent about 4 weeks solid; reviewing tv's, and stalking them as well. I have been to BB, HHREGG, as well as a few other specialty stores, and spent 2 to 4 hours in each store. (i'm retired so i can afford to do so).I have asked the sales people to insert proprietary 3d disks. The only thing that has not been possible is to attach my Xfinity/Comcast cable box to these tv's to compare the difference in picture quality.The first thing that needs to be said is that none of these stores selling said tv's have calibrated them. So some tv's that are highly rated on the internet, look terrible in the store.One example is  the Panasonic 65" ZT Series Plasma HDTV, which was placed directly in bright lights in the hhregg store. The poor tv looked lousy and dark...Sniff.Another thing that you should know about the reviewer (me) is that I have been actively creating 3d objects and graphics for years. Resolution and color representation are so important to me.Couple this with the fact that I have light to moderate Aspergers. I can focus on microscopic details and differences for hours. Idiotic perfection of sorts. It's a blessing and a curse.The contenders we have selected for purchase (within our budget) as of today are :Sony 65" XBR Series LED Ultra HDTVSamsung 75" Series 7 LED HDTV - UN75F7100Sony KDL-70R550A 70-Inch 120Hz 1080pVIZIO M801d-A3 80-Inch 1080pPanasonic 65" ZT Series Plasma HDTV.As of this writing, we have eliminated the Sony KDL-70R550A. Although it is by far the most affordable ($2100), the colors and picture quality are simply inferior to the others above.We are also probably going to eliminate the Panasonic plasma for whatever reason, the 3d was not amazing, and it's only a 65" screen.If you mention the name VIZIO to me, I will start getting cold sweats. Although the Vizio M series affords plenty of great reviews, I still have a psychological barrier towards stereotypical cheaper brands. Quite frankly, I also have a barriers towards Kia and Hyundai, although they are great cars.I have had plenty of time to observe the vizio M801d-A3 and the Vizio M701d-A3 in action. Despite my mistrust in the brand, the picture both in 2d and 3d is excellent. Many reviewers  have said that the screen is too reflective and that there are problems operating the remote control on these models though. The screen on the Samsung 75" Series 7 LED HDTV - UN75F7100, is also just as reflective. The color representation and picture quality of the Samsung is superior to the Vizio though.Anyone who is considering the purchase of a Sharp Aquos should definitely compare/study Vizio M models as well. Personally, I would buy the Vizio over the Sharps, I prefer the Vizios image over the Sharps, and the Sharp 80" is very expensive too compared to Vizio. If anyone here is considering a Samsung 7100 or 8000 LED, do not even bother checking out the Vizios or the Sharp models.I hesitated a long time Over the Samsung models, and when my research was over, I invited my wife to review the results.The 3 models we studied were the Samsung 4k ultra @ 65" and both the UN75F7100 and UNF8000 both at 75".I saw very little picture quality difference between the UN75F7100 and UNF8000, however the 8000 series is much more expensive. For this reason we eliminated it.My wife and I have Apple Tv at home, so we are less interested in Apps and gaming. We like watching movies both in 2d and 3d.Next we compared the 4K ultra Tv's, the sony Xbr and the Samsung 4k. Both have a 65" screen.For some odd reason we did not find the Samsung 4k impressive. We played a few Sony Demos on it as well as watched a few 3d movies on it, and It was marginally better than the Samsung UN75F7100. Also the 4k is more expensive by $2000.The 3d movies we watched were nearly just as good on the UN75F7100. We also found that the UN75F7100 had better COLOR REPRESENTATION...wait let me explain !!!The sony XBR 4K.If money were no object, I would buy the 85" model of the Sony XBR 4 K ULTRA, right now.The sony XBR is by far the best picture quality and especially COLOR representation we have seen. By far!!!If you do not believe me, get a few 2d~3d movies you guys like, and go and force the sales people to play them on the Sony.Sony is reluctant to allow third party content to play on their demo Tv's because they want to show you their demo stuff (that looks exceptional BTW. But if you are going to spend 5k on a TV it's your right to be anally retentive.The picture quality, the perfection of color, and the passive 3d blew us away. This tv does an amazing job at up scaling content to a higher a definition of clarity and color.For me, the difference between the Sony and most of the other Tv's was like creating a picture in Photoshop at 72 pixels per inch and then creating the same picture at 300ppi, then comparing the two. Forget the fact that there is little to no real 4k content yet. This tv has by far the best picture.The huge dilemma we now have is. Which of these two tv's are we going to buy? The samsung UN75F7100 or the Sony 4K. The samsung is much larger +10", but the Sony is better quality in picture and color.We found that the samsung UN75F7100 was not far behind in color, but there was still a visible difference. The sony image is much crisper/clearer. A higher definition, no doubt.The samsung screen is much like the vizio, extremely reflective to any object that may be in front of it.We preferred the sony's screen.Another dilemma we have is that we view tv from 12 feet away, so logically the 75" samsung would be a better choice. Price wise they are more or less the same given a few hundred dollars.We did find the Samsungs stand quite unpractical. Due to the relatively long TV one needs two small tables at either end of the tv. We cannot wall mount it.The speakers are no doubt better on the sony which has speakers on either side of the screen. Anyhow, all these tv's warrant an added sound bar, so who cares about the original factory sound?Sony is coming out with the same tv in a few weeks without the speakers, So i may wait until I finally decide which of these two to purchase.Hope this review helps you guys choose a tv.
